text: hi guys it's Elise from my cupcake
addiction and today I'm going to be
showing you how to make this amazing
Princess Anna and Queen Elsa surprise
inside pinata cake this is perfect if
you're a frozen fan and you just can't
decide which of the two girls you want
to have grace in your party table if you
haven't already seen it make sure that
you check out my frozen princess
playlist I have so many great ideas to
themed your frozen party and all of your
sweet treats are covered within it I
will link to that one down below to make
your frozen cake you're going to need
both a Princess Anna and Queen Elsa
frozen doll and try to find the ones if
you can that have the plastic clothing
on the top half of their bodice --es
today I've pre baked my cake so I'm
using four seven inch by one inch high
cake layers for this tutorial and I've
also got a circle cutter I'll leave
dimensions for that in the description
box below but basically you need one
that's wide enough to fit both of your
princess bottoms in it at the same time
I've pre colored my fondant so I've got
some white some Wilton sky-blue and then
some navy blue so for the navy blue it's
a tough color to get but what you want
is three parts Wilton royal blue to one
part Wilton black and that's going to
get you that navy blue it's also best to
make these dark colors the day before as
the color will develop a little bit more
overnight as it settles because we're
making a delicious pinata cake and it's
going to be full of candy I've got
frozen themed candy today so I'm using
some dark blue and light blue M&Ms some
blue jelly beans and some white
snowflakes but any blueish or whitish
shades of candy will be perfect here
I've got some tap water a paintbrush an
offset spatula a serrated edge knife a
fondant rolling pin and a pizza cutter
I've got some luster dust or some
shimmer powders today and I'm using a
purple a pink and a green any brand will
do it really doesn't matter and that's
just to create the effect we're going to
paint on the details for the bottom of
Anna's dress as an optional extra I've
got a snowflake plunge cutter which I'm
going to team up with my white fondant
I'm not going to show you how to make
those today because I showed you how to
do those in my cupcake tutorial so make
sure you check that out if you haven't
used a plunge cutter before and I'm
making those the day before so they've
got a bit of time to set and get a bit
of firmness to
them I've also got a little bit of
Wilton columnist in silver and I've got
some cornflour in a shaker I've got a
batch of our buttercream frosting which
I'll link to the recipe for down below
and I've colored that with that Wilton
sky-blue and I've also got some cake
boards so for my cake boards I'm using a
7-inch cardboard board to go underneath
my cakes and then I've got a temporary
board you can see I've got a bit of
nonstick mat on there to stop that top
board from spinning around that
temporary boards the one that's designed
to get messy and then I've got a
secondary board which I'm actually going
to cover in some of this beautiful
glitter scrapbooking paper so I'll show
you how to do that first to cover your
cake board you just want to take some of
that glitter scrapbooking paper and use
a marker to trace around the outside
edge of your cake board use some
scissors just to cut around it and then
you want to take some craft glue and
apply generous amount to the board
before popping your circle of
scrapbooking paper on and flattening it
down drive that face down for about six
to twelve hours so it doesn't lift at
the edges you'll see I've got a little
bit of non-slip mat that stops my board
from sliding around now you just want to
take a bit of a smear of your
buttercream frosting and just pop it on
the board before sticking down your
first layer of cake take your circle
cutter now and don't go all the way
through your cake just go about halfway
down the depth spin it around so it cuts
out the full circle and then using a
knife just use that to kind of burrow
the cake out a little bit place on some
of your buttercream frosting using that
offset spatula and if your cakes are
quite domed here you will want to trim
the tops off so they're nice and flat I
had pretty flat cakes to start off with
so I'm not going to worry Longo's or a
second layer of cake and then once again
just cut that center circle out if it
doesn't go all the way through to shoot
your serrated edge knife just to take
the last little section out but that
nice circle cut will give you that nice
circle shape as your frosting in between
these layers you don't want to put
frosting on the inside of the cake where
you've put that circle cutter or else
your pinata candy is going to get all
stuck to it and it's not going to spill
out nicely once all four of your layers
are stacked don't frost the top take
your serrated edge knife and on a bit of
a gradient or on a bit of an angle you
just want to trim it down so that it's
kind of like a dome shape this would
also be a great shape for a minion cake
I'm also going to trim off all of the
sides in all the edges so what I've got
is quite a high round dome using your
spatula you'll want to work some of that
frosting back and forward into the sides
of the cake really thin layers this is
going to create a crumb coat which is
going to trap all of those crumbs
you can set that off in the freezer for
about five or ten minutes while you wrap
your dolls if you'd like it'd be a bit
firm it'll work with make sure that when
you wrap your dolls you've taken off all
of their accessories lift their arms in
the air and make sure that no part of
the doll is going to be touching the
cake put in about two handfuls of that
candy and then you can take your Queen
Elsa doll and stick her in ever so
slightly tilted towards what's going to
be the front of your cake once she's in
it then you can take your honour and
push her in as well that candy is kind
of going to move around and make way for
their feet and then you want to take
some more of your pieces of candy and
just pop them in the gaps in between the
girls bottoms and give your cake a
little shake so that it all sort of
settles down to the bottom and you can
fill it up as full as you can to keep
everything in place just take a bit more
of that frosting and using this
Batchelor kind of frost to the girls
into the dress and frost seal the candy
and now you want to apply a nice
generous coat of buttercream frosting so
that crumb coat is just designed to set
the cake this is going to be what sticks
our fondant down once you've got a fair
bit of it on there you can scrape it off
so that it's as nice and smooth as you
can possibly get it with this you want
to work quite quickly because
buttercream will start to crust and you
need to get that fondant on there within
about ten or fifteen minutes otherwise
it's not going to have anything to stick
to for your fondant sprinkle down some
cornflour and then roll your fondant out
nice and thin
I'm making a fondant disc here which I
need because I've covered that board in
non edible glitter paper and I don't
want any glitter on the bottom of my
cake so that fondant I'm cutting out in
a circle just tracing around a bowl
applying a little bit of water to the
back of it and sticking it down so I've
still got an inch or so of that
beautiful glitter poking out all the way
around the edges but anyway my cakes
gonna touch is now protected by edible
fondant on your knife clean presentation
board just pop another smear of that
buttercream frosting and then you two
offset spatula just it gently lift the
girls up placing your fingers underneath
either side position them down on the
board and then sort of walk your fingers
right towards the back of that cake
board and then drop it that's the
easiest way to get the cake down without
making a mess roll out another Sennett
piece of fondant and we're going to cut
kind of like a weird triangle shape so I
don't have a template for this and you
want to go by eye but make it bigger
rather than smaller because we can
always trim it once it's on the cake
pick it up and drape it over making sure
that you secure the waste first of all
so make sure that you've got Elsa's
waste
where you want it and then you can work
on making sure the sides are going to
roughly halfway down the front and back
of your cake the idea here is you want
this dress to kind of come out in line
with that fondant disc that you put down
so just pull it out a little bit and
then I'm just using my fingers to just
roughly make some little ripple sort of
lines in the dress to give it a bit of
texture taking your pizza cut it out cut
along the edge slightly out from that
fondant disc and then I'm going to sort
of lift it out and we're going to make
these little ripples or I guess little
folds in the bottom of the dress you can
see I'm just pinching it here and
sliding it up a little bit don't put too
many of these or it looks messy I'm
pinching another one here and then I'm
going to kick up a little section here
it just creates that movement and that
flow in our Queen Elsa's dress your
Wilton spray should be about 30
centimetres away from the cake and just
spray it in short bursts this is going
to give the ice queen shimmer and it's
actually not going to be silver it's
just going to be like a really light
shimmer you want to cut the exact same
shape that you cut for Queen Elsa for
Princess Anna so cut it out out of your
navy blue fondant and once again wrap it
around securing the waist first once the
waist is secure just pull it out so that
your two sides meet up about it evenly
as they can you can trim this off with
some scissors if you need to pull that
dress out give it a couple of those
little texture lines just at the top and
then use the pizza cutter to cut it
right up flush with that fondant disk
underneath I've opted to hand paint on
the details in Anna's dress because
they're not that complicated so I've got
my three different colors of luster dust
I'm mixing my luster dust today with
some water rather than alcohol because I
know a lot of you guys don't have access
to alcohol when you're mixing with water
just pop in a generous amount of powder
with a couple of drops of water you want
to paint kind of like a scalloped effect
along the bottom half inch or so of the
dress because we're using water here
that's going to take about 12 hours to
dry if you use alcohol it will dry
almost instantly using my green now I'm
painting on a dot and then for little
lines to shorter and to longer for those
little details down the very bottom and
then my stem detail before moving on to
the pink which I'm mixing in the exact
same way just with water and for these
flowers I just made like a little half
circle with a dot in the middle finally
I'm going to finish it off with like a
little flower on top of those mini green
plants and two little dots on either
side of
the stems now some of you guys are going
to want to kill me here because yes I am
cutting Queen Elsa's dress and I'm also
going to cut for instance an escape I've
opted to do this because it fits the
cake a lot better but if these are a
gift you might just want to put one cape
coming down one side and the other going
down the other side as you redress your
Queen Elsa just position her cape so
that it's sort of on her side of the
cake and then pop your little cape on
Princess Anna if they're not sticking in
place you can use a little bit of water
on that fondant just to slightly hold
the cakes or their coats in place
finally I'm going to take a couple of
those snowflakes put a little bit of
water on the back of them and just sort
of scatter them down around the bottom
of Queen Elsa's dress so that's it we're
done they've got your stunning frozen
sisters double princess cake perfect for
any frozen party and full of that
amazing candy I was originally inspired
by a picture that one of you sent in
from a company called cup and cake who I
will link to down below thanks so much
for the inspiration and I hope you guys
liked my version of this awesome
sister's cake as always thanks very much
for tuning in to my cupcake addiction
